title: Theorems of Pythagoras, isosceles triangles, and intersecting chords

blocks.name: angval
blocks.content: Define the angle function, which takes two complex numbers, treated as vectors from the origin, and returns the angle between them, in the range ` ( - _pi , _pi ] ` . To convert from the geometry notation, ` m A B C ` , the measure of the angle with legs ` A B ` , ` C B ` where ` C ` is more counterclockwise for positive angles, is represented by ` ( ( C - B ) F ( A - B ) ) ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm angval(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0))), wceq(co(c0, c2, c1), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)))))
  -| wceq(c2, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
} = {
  syl2anbr(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wceq(co(c0, c2, c1), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)))), wcel(c0, cdif(cc, csn(nat0))), wcel(c1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0))))
  eldifsn(c0, cc, nat0)
  eldifsn(c1, cc, nat0)
  ovmpt2a(s0, s1, c0, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), c1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), c2, cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0))), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0)))))
  fveq2d(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))), cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)), wa(wceq(cv(s0), c0), wceq(cv(s1), c1)))
  fveq2d(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0)), co(c1, cdiv, c0), wa(wceq(cv(s0), c0), wceq(cv(s1), c1)))
  ancoms(wceq(cv(s0), c0), wceq(cv(s1), c1), wceq(co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0)), co(c1, cdiv, c0)))
  oveq12(cv(s1), c1, cv(s0), c0, cdiv)
  fvex(cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)))
  diff.cdif.s(s0, cc, csn(nat0))
  diff.cc.s(s0)
  diff.csn.s(s0, nat0)
  diff.nat0.s(s0)
  diff.cfv.s(s0, cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)))
  diff.cim.s(s0)
  diff.cfv.s(s0, clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0))
  diff.clog.s(s0)
  diff.co.s(s0, c1, cdiv, c0)
  diff.cdiv.s(s0)
  diff.cdif.s(s1, cc, csn(nat0))
  diff.cc.s(s1)
  diff.csn.s(s1, nat0)
  diff.nat0.s(s1)
  diff.cfv.s(s1, cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)))
  diff.cim.s(s1)
  diff.cfv.s(s1, clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0))
  diff.clog.s(s1)
  diff.co.s(s1, c1, cdiv, c0)
  diff.cdiv.s(s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm angval(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  ⊢ (((c0 ∈ ℂ ∧ c0 ≠ 0)∧(c1 ∈ ℂ ∧ c1 ≠ 0))→(c0[c2]c1)=(Im `(log `(c1[÷]c0))))
  ⊣ c2 =(s0 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 }), s1 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 })↦(Im `(log `(s1[÷]s0))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c1)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c1)
} = {
  syl2anbr((c0 ∈ ℂ ∧ c0 ≠ 0), (c1 ∈ ℂ ∧ c1 ≠ 0), (c0[c2]c1)=(Im `(log `(c1[÷]c0))), c0 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 }), c1 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 }))
  eldifsn(c0, cc, nat0)
  eldifsn(c1, cc, nat0)
  ovmpt2a(s0, s1, c0, (ℂ \ { 0 }), c1, (ℂ \ { 0 }), c2, (Im `(log `(c1[÷]c0))), (Im `(log `(s1[÷]s0))))
  fveq2d(cim, (log `(s1[÷]s0)), (log `(c1[÷]c0)), (s0 = c0 ∧ s1 = c1))
  fveq2d(clog, (s1[÷]s0), (c1[÷]c0), (s0 = c0 ∧ s1 = c1))
  ancoms(s0 = c0, s1 = c1, (s1[÷]s0)=(c1[÷]c0))
  oveq12(s1, c1, s0, c0, cdiv)
  fvex(cim, (log `(c1[÷]c0)))
  diff.cdif.s(s0, cc, { 0 })
  diff.cc.s(s0)
  diff.csn.s(s0, nat0)
  diff.nat0.s(s0)
  diff.cfv.s(s0, cim, (log `(c1[÷]c0)))
  diff.cim.s(s0)
  diff.cfv.s(s0, clog, (c1[÷]c0))
  diff.clog.s(s0)
  diff.co.s(s0, c1, cdiv, c0)
  diff.cdiv.s(s0)
  diff.cdif.s(s1, cc, { 0 })
  diff.cc.s(s1)
  diff.csn.s(s1, nat0)
  diff.nat0.s(s1)
  diff.cfv.s(s1, cim, (log `(c1[÷]c0)))
  diff.cim.s(s1)
  diff.cfv.s(s1, clog, (c1[÷]c0))
  diff.clog.s(s1)
  diff.co.s(s1, c1, cdiv, c0)
  diff.cdiv.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: angcan
blocks.content: Cancel a constant multiplier in the angle function. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm angcan(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))), wceq(co(co(c2, cmul, c0), c3, co(c2, cmul, c1)), co(c0, c3, c1)))
  -| wceq(c3, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
} = {
  3eqtr4d(co(co(c2, cmul, c0), c3, co(c2, cmul, c1)), co(c0, c3, c1), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(co(c2, cmul, c1), cdiv, co(c2, cmul, c0)))), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0))), w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  fveq2d(cim, cfv(clog, co(co(c2, cmul, c1), cdiv, co(c2, cmul, c0))), cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)), w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  fveq2d(clog, co(co(c2, cmul, c1), cdiv, co(c2, cmul, c0)), co(c1, cdiv, c0), w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  divcan5d(c2, c1, c0, w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  syl22anc(w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))), wceq(co(co(c2, cmul, c0), c3, co(c2, cmul, c1)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(co(c2, cmul, c1), cdiv, co(c2, cmul, c0))))), wcel(co(c2, cmul, c0), cc), wne(co(c2, cmul, c0), nat0), wcel(co(c2, cmul, c1), cc), wne(co(c2, cmul, c1), nat0))
  mulcld(c2, c0, w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  mulne0d(c2, c0, w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  simp1l(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0)))
  simp1r(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0)))
  mulcld(c2, c1, w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  mulne0d(c2, c1, w3a(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))))
  simp3l(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))
  simp2l(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0)))
  simp3r(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))
  simp2r(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0)))
  angval(s0, s1, co(c2, cmul, c0), co(c2, cmul, c1), c3)
  3adant3(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0)), wceq(co(c0, c3, c1), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c1, cdiv, c0)))))
  angval(s0, s1, c0, c1, c3)
  diff.co.s(s0, c2, cmul, c0)
  diff.co.s(s0, c2, cmul, c1)
  diff.cmul.s(s0)
  diff.co.s(s1, c2, cmul, c0)
  diff.co.s(s1, c2, cmul, c1)
  diff.cmul.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: angneg
blocks.content: Cancel a negative sign in the angle function. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm angneg(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0))), wceq(co(cneg(c0), c2, cneg(c1)), co(c0, c2, c1)))
  -| wceq(c2, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
} = {
  eqtr3d(co(cneg(c0), c2, cneg(c1)), co(c0, c2, c1), co(co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c0), c2, co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c1)), wa(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0))))
  oveq12d(co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c0), c2, co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c1), cneg(c0), cneg(c1), wa(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0))))
  ad2antrr(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wceq(co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c0), cneg(c0)))
  mulm1(c0)
  ad2antrl(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0), wceq(co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c1), cneg(c1)))
  mulm1(c1)
  mp3an3(wa(wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0)), wa(wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0)), wceq(co(co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c0), c2, co(cneg(nat1), cmul, c1)), co(c0, c2, c1)), wa(wcel(cneg(nat1), cc), wne(cneg(nat1), nat0)))
  pm3.2i(wcel(cneg(nat1), cc), wne(cneg(nat1), nat0))
  neg1cn()
  neg1ne0()
  angcan(s0, s1, c0, c1, cneg(nat1), c2)
  diff.cneg.s(s0, nat1)
  diff.nat1.s(s0)
  diff.cneg.s(s1, nat1)
  diff.nat1.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: angvald
blocks.content: The (signed) angle between two vectors is the argument of their quotient. Deduction form of ~ angval . (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm angvald(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(co(c0, c1, c2), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0)))))
  -| wceq(c1, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, nat0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c2, nat0))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
} = {
  syl22anc(w0, wceq(co(c0, c1, c2), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0)))), wcel(c0, cc), wne(c0, nat0), wcel(c2, cc), wne(c2, nat0))
  angval(s0, s1, c0, c2, c1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm angvald(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(c0[c1]c2)=(Im `(log `(c2[÷]c0))))
  ⊣ c1 =(s0 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 }), s1 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 })↦(Im `(log `(s1[÷]s0))))
  ⊣ (w0 → c0 ∈ ℂ)
  ⊣ (w0 → c0 ≠ 0)
  ⊣ (w0 → c2 ∈ ℂ)
  ⊣ (w0 → c2 ≠ 0)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c2)
} = {
  syl22anc(w0, (c0[c1]c2)=(Im `(log `(c2[÷]c0))), c0 ∈ ℂ, c0 ≠ 0, c2 ∈ ℂ, c2 ≠ 0)
  angval(s0, s1, c0, c2, c1)
}

blocks.name: angcld
blocks.content: The (signed) angle between two vectors is in ` ( -u _pi (,] _pi ) ` . Deduction form. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm angcld(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wcel(co(c0, c1, c2), co(cneg(cpi), cioc, cpi)))
  -| wceq(c1, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, nat0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c2, nat0))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
} = {
  eqeltrd(co(c0, c1, c2), co(cneg(cpi), cioc, cpi), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0))), w0)
  angvald(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, w0)
  logimclad(co(c2, cdiv, c0), w0)
  divcld(c2, c0, w0)
  divne0d(c2, c0, w0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm angcld(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(c0[c1]c2)∈(-u(π)[(,]]π))
  ⊣ c1 =(s0 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 }), s1 ∈(ℂ \ { 0 })↦(Im `(log `(s1[÷]s0))))
  ⊣ (w0 → c0 ∈ ℂ)
  ⊣ (w0 → c0 ≠ 0)
  ⊣ (w0 → c2 ∈ ℂ)
  ⊣ (w0 → c2 ≠ 0)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c2)
} = {
  eqeltrd((c0[c1]c2), (-u(π)[(,]]π), (Im `(log `(c2[÷]c0))), w0)
  angvald(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, w0)
  logimclad((c2[÷]c0), w0)
  divcld(c2, c0, w0)
  divne0d(c2, c0, w0)
}

blocks.name: angrteqvd
blocks.content: Two vectors are at a right angle iff their quotient is purely imaginary. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm angrteqvd(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(wcel(co(c0, c1, c2), cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)))), wceq(cfv(cre, co(c2, cdiv, c0)), nat0)))
  -| wceq(c1, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, nat0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c2, nat0))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
} = {
  3bitr2d(w0, wcel(co(c0, c1, c2), cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)))), wceq(cfv(cre, co(c2, cdiv, c0)), nat0), wcel(cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0))), cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)))), wceq(cfv(ccos, cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0)))), nat0))
  eleq1d(co(c0, c1, c2), cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0))), w0)
  angvald(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, w0)
  syl(w0, wb(wceq(cfv(ccos, cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0)))), nat0), wcel(cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0))), cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))))), wcel(cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0))), co(cneg(cpi), cioc, cpi)))
  logimclad(co(c2, cdiv, c0), w0)
  coseq0negpitopi(cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(c2, cdiv, c0))))
  cosarg0d(co(c2, cdiv, c0), w0)
  divcld(c2, c0, w0)
  divne0d(c2, c0, w0)
}

blocks.name: cosangneg2d
blocks.content: The cosine of the angle between ` X ` and ` -u Y ` is the negative of that between ` X ` and ` Y ` . If A, B and C are collinear points, this implies that the cosines of DBA and DBC sum to zero, i.e., that DBA and DBC are supplementary. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm cosangneg2d(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(cfv(ccos, co(c0, c1, cneg(c2))), cneg(cfv(ccos, co(c0, c1, c2)))))
  -| wceq(c1, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, nat0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c2, nat0))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)

blocks.name: ang180lem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ ang180 . Show that the "revolution number" ` N ` is an integer, using ~ efeq1 to show that since the product of the three arguments ` A , 1 / ( 1 - A ) , ( A - 1 ) / A ` is ` -u 1 ` , the sum of the logarithms must be an integer multiple of ` 2 _pi _i ` away from ` _pi _i = log ( -u 1 ) ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)

blocks.name: ang180lem2
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ ang180 . Show that the revolution number ` N ` is strictly between ` -u 2 ` and ` 1 ` . Both bounds are established by iterating using the bounds on the imaginary part of the logarithm, ~ logimcl , but the resulting bound gives only ` N <_ 1 ` for the upper bound. The case ` N = 1 ` is not ruled out here, but it is in some sense an "edge case" that can only happen under very specific conditions; in particular we show that all the angle arguments ` A , 1 / ( 1 - A ) , ( A - 1 ) / A ` must lie on the negative real axis, which is a contradiction because clearly if ` A ` is negative then the other two are positive real. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)

blocks.name: ang180lem3
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ ang180 . Since ~ ang180lem1 shows that ` N ` is an integer and ~ ang180lem2 shows that ` N ` is strictly between ` -u 2 ` and ` 1 ` , it follows that ` N e. { -u 1 , 0 } ` , and these two cases correspond to the two possible values for ` T ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)

blocks.name: ang180
blocks.content: The sum of angles ` m A B C + m B C A + m C A B ` in a triangle adds up to either ` _pi ` or ` -u _pi ` , i.e. 180 degrees. (The sign is due to the two possible orientations of vertex arrangement and our signed notion of angle). This is Metamath 100 proof #27. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Sep-2014.)

blocks.name: lawcos
blocks.content: Law of cosines (also known as the Al-Kashi theorem or the generalized Pythagorean theorem, or the cosine formula or cosine rule). Given three distinct points A, B, and C, prove a relationship between their segment lengths. This theorem is expressed using the complex number plane as a plane, where ` F ` is the signed angle construct (as used in ~ ang180 ), ` X ` is the distance of line segment BC, ` Y ` is the distance of line segment AC, ` Z ` is the distance of line segment AB, and ` O ` is the signed angle m/_ BCA on the complex plane. We translate triangle ABC to move C to the origin (C-C), B to U=(B-C), and A to V=(A-C), then use lemma ~ lawcoslem1 to prove this algebraically simpler case. The Metamath convention is to use a signed angle; in this case the sign doesn't matter because we use the cosine of the angle (see ~ cosneg ). The Pythagorean theorem ~ pythag is a special case of the law of cosines. The theorem's expression and approach were suggested by Mario Carneiro. This is Metamath 100 proof #94. (Contributed by David A. Wheeler, 12-Jun-2015.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: pythag
blocks.content: Pythagorean theorem. Given three distinct points A, B, and C that form a right triangle (with the right angle at C), prove a relationship between their segment lengths. This theorem is expressed using the complex number plane as a plane, where ` F ` is the signed angle construct (as used in ~ ang180 ), ` X ` is the distance of line segment BC, ` Y ` is the distance of line segment AC, ` Z ` is the distance of line segment AB (the hypotenuse), and ` O ` is the signed right angle m/_ BCA. We use the law of cosines ~ lawcos to prove this, along with simple trigonometry facts like ~ coshalfpi and ~ cosneg . (Contributed by David A. Wheeler, 13-Jun-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm pythag(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7) {

  -| wceq(c7, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))
  -| wceq(c6, cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c1)))
  -| wceq(c3, co(co(c1, cmin, c2), c7, co(c0, cmin, c2)))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)

  3eqtrd(co(c4, cexp, nat2), co(co(c5, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c6, cexp, nat2)), co(co(co(c5, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c6, cexp, nat2)), cmin, co(nat2, cmul, co(co(c5, cmul, c6), cmul, cfv(ccos, c3)))), co(co(co(c5, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c6, cexp, nat2)), cmin, nat0), w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), wa(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2)), wcel(c3, cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))))))

  lawcos(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c4, c5, c6, c3, c7)
  oveq2d(co(co(c5, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c6, cexp, nat2)), cmin, co(nat2, cmul, co(co(c5, cmul, c6), cmul, cfv(ccos, c3))), nat0, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), wa(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2)), wcel(c3, cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))))))
  syl6eq(co(nat2, cmul, co(co(c5, cmul, c6), cmul, cfv(ccos, c3))), nat0, co(nat2, cmul, nat0), w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), wa(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2)), wcel(c3, cpr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cneg(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))))))

blocks.name: isosctr
blocks.content: Isosceles triangle theorem. This is Metamath 100 proof #65. (Contributed by Saveliy Skresanov, 1-Jan-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm isosctr(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))), wceq(co(co(c2, cmin, c0), c3, co(c1, cmin, c0)), co(co(c0, cmin, c1), c3, co(c2, cmin, c1))))
  -| wceq(c3, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
} = {
  3eqtr3d(co(co(c2, cmin, c0), c3, co(c1, cmin, c0)), co(co(c0, cmin, c1), c3, co(c2, cmin, c1)), co(cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), c3, co(co(c1, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c0, cmin, c2))), co(co(co(c0, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c1, cmin, c2)), c3, cneg(co(c1, cmin, c2))), w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  syl231anc(w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))), wceq(co(cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), c3, co(co(c1, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c0, cmin, c2))), co(co(co(c0, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c1, cmin, c2)), c3, cneg(co(c1, cmin, c2)))), wcel(co(c0, cmin, c2), cc), wcel(co(c1, cmin, c2), cc), wne(co(c0, cmin, c2), nat0), wne(co(c1, cmin, c2), nat0), wne(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmin, c2)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))))
  subcld(c0, c2, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  subcld(c1, c2, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  subne0d(c0, c2, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  simp21(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))))
  subne0d(c1, c2, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  simp22(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))))
  mpbird(w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))), wne(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmin, c2)), wne(c0, c1))

  necon3bid(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmin, c2), c0, c1, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  3ad2ant1(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))), wb(wceq(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmin, c2)), wceq(c0, c1)))
  subcan2(c0, c1, c2)
  simp3(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))))
  isosctrlem3(s0, s1, co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmin, c2), c3)
  oveq12d(cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), c3, co(co(c1, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c0, cmin, c2)), co(c2, cmin, c0), co(c1, cmin, c0), w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  negsubdi2d(c0, c2, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  nnncan2d(c1, c2, c0, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  oveq12d(co(co(c0, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c1, cmin, c2)), c3, cneg(co(c1, cmin, c2)), co(c0, cmin, c1), co(c2, cmin, c1), w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  nnncan2d(c0, c2, c1, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  simp11(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))))
  negsubdi2d(c1, c2, w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc)), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2)))))
  simp12(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(c2, cc), w3a(wne(c0, c2), wne(c1, c2), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmin, c2)), cfv(cabs, co(c1, cmin, c2))))

blocks.name: ssscongptld
blocks.content: If two triangles have equal sides, one angle in one triangle has the same cosine as the corresponding angle in the other triangle. This is a partial form of the SSS congruence theorem. This theorem is proven by using ~ lawcos on both triangles to express one side in terms of the other two, and then equating these expressions and reducing this algebraically to get an equality of cosines of angles. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)

thm affineequiv(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cc))
} = {
  bitrd(w0, wceq(c0, co(co(c1, cmul, c2), caddc, co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c3))), wceq(co(c3, cmin, c0), co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), wceq(co(co(c3, cmin, c0), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), nat0))

  eqeq2d(c0, co(co(c1, cmul, c2), caddc, co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c3)), co(c0, caddc, co(co(c3, cmin, c0), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)))), w0)
  3eqtr4d(co(co(c1, cmul, c2), caddc, co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c3)), co(c0, caddc, co(co(c3, cmin, c0), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)))), co(co(c1, cmul, c2), caddc, co(c3, cmin, co(c1, cmul, c3))), co(c3, cmin, co(co(c1, cmul, c3), cmin, co(c1, cmul, c2))), w0)
  eqtr2d(co(co(c1, cmul, c2), caddc, co(c3, cmin, co(c1, cmul, c3))), co(c3, cmin, co(co(c1, cmul, c3), cmin, co(c1, cmul, c2))), co(co(c3, cmin, co(c1, cmul, c3)), caddc, co(c1, cmul, c2)), w0)
  subsubd(c3, co(c1, cmul, c3), co(c1, cmul, c2), w0)
  addcomd(co(c3, cmin, co(c1, cmul, c3)), co(c1, cmul, c2), w0)
  subcld(c3, co(c1, cmul, c3), w0)

  subdird(nat1, c1, c3, w0)

  subcanad(co(c3, cmin, c2), co(c3, cmin, c0), co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), w0)
  subcld(c3, c0, w0)
  mulcld(c1, co(c3, cmin, c2), w0)
  eqeq12d(co(co(c3, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c3, cmin, c0)), co(co(c3, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), co(c0, cmin, c2), co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), w0)
  nnncan1d(c3, c2, c0, w0)
  eqtr2d(co(co(c3, cmin, c2), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), co(co(nat1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), w0)
  subdird(nat1, c1, co(c3, cmin, c2), w0)
  1cnd(w0)
  oveq1d(co(nat1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), cmin, co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), co(c3, cmin, c2), w0)
  mulid2d(co(c3, cmin, c2), w0)
  subcld(c3, c2, w0)
}

blocks.name: affineequiv3
blocks.content: Equivalence between two ways of expressing ` A ` as an affine combination of ` B ` and ` C ` . (Contributed by AV, 22-Jan-2023.)

thm affineequiv3(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(wceq(c0, co(co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c2), caddc, co(c1, cmul, c3))), wceq(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cc))
} = {
  3bitrd(w0, wceq(c0, co(co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c2), caddc, co(c1, cmul, c3))), wceq(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), wceq(c0, co(co(c1, cmul, c3), caddc, co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c2))), wceq(co(c2, cmin, c0), co(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3))))
  eqeq2d(c0, co(co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c2), caddc, co(c1, cmul, c3)), co(co(c1, cmul, c3), caddc, co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c2)), w0)
  addcomd(co(co(nat1, cmin, c1), cmul, c2), co(c1, cmul, c3), w0)
  mulcld(co(nat1, cmin, c1), c2, w0)
  subcld(nat1, c1, w0)
  1cnd(w0)
  mulcld(c1, c3, w0)
  affineequiv(c0, c1, c3, c2, w0)
  3bitrd(w0, wceq(co(c2, cmin, c0), co(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3))), wceq(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), wceq(cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), co(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3))), wceq(cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), cneg(co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)))))
  eqeq1d(co(c2, cmin, c0), co(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3)), cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), w0)
  eqcomd(co(c2, cmin, c0), cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), w0)
  negsubdi2d(c0, c2, w0)
  eqeq2d(cneg(co(c0, cmin, c2)), co(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3)), cneg(co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), w0)
  eqtrd(co(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3)), cneg(co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2))), co(c1, cmul, cneg(co(c3, cmin, c2))), w0)
  oveq2d(c1, cmul, co(c2, cmin, c3), cneg(co(c3, cmin, c2)), w0)
  eqcomd(co(c2, cmin, c3), cneg(co(c3, cmin, c2)), w0)
  negsubdi2d(c3, c2, w0)
  mulneg2d(c1, co(c3, cmin, c2), w0)
  neg11ad(co(c0, cmin, c2), co(c1, cmul, co(c3, cmin, c2)), w0)
  subcld(c0, c2, w0)
  mulcld(c1, co(c3, cmin, c2), w0)
  subcld(c3, c2, w0)
}

thm angpieqvdlem2(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {

  divcld(co(c0, cmin, c1), co(c2, cmin, c1), w0)

  angvald(s0, s1, co(c2, cmin, c1), c3, co(c0, cmin, c1), w0)

blocks.name: angpined
blocks.content: If the angle at ABC is ` _pi ` , then A is not equal to C. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm angpined(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wi(wceq(co(co(c0, cmin, c1), c2, co(c3, cmin, c1)), cpi), wne(c0, c3)))
  -| wceq(c2, cmpo(s0, s1, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s1), cdiv, cv(s0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, c1))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c1, c3))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
} = {
  sylbird(w0, wceq(co(co(c0, cmin, c1), c2, co(c3, cmin, c1)), cpi), wne(c0, c3), wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp))
  angpieqvdlem2(s0, s1, c3, c1, c0, c2, w0)
  syl6ib(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp), wne(c0, c3), wne(c3, c0))
  ex(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp), wne(c3, c0))
  mpi(wa(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp)), wne(c3, c0), wn(wcel(cneg(nat1), crp)))
  mpbi(wn(wcel(cneg(nat1), crp)), wcel(nat1, crp))
  1rp()
  mp2an(wb(wcel(nat1, crp), wn(wcel(cneg(nat1), crp))), wcel(nat1, cr), wne(nat1, nat0))
  1re()
  ax-1ne0()
  rpneg(nat1)
  necon3bd(c3, c0, wa(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp)), wcel(cneg(nat1), crp))
  ex(wa(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp)), wceq(c3, c0), wcel(cneg(nat1), crp))
  eqeltrrd(cneg(nat1), crp, cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), wa(wa(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp)), wceq(c3, c0)))
  negeqd(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1)), nat1, wa(wa(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp)), wceq(c3, c0)))
  adantlr(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp), wceq(c3, c0), wceq(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1)), nat1))
  diveq1bd(co(c3, cmin, c1), co(c0, cmin, c1), wa(w0, wceq(c3, c0)))
  adantr(w0, wceq(c3, c0), wcel(co(c0, cmin, c1), cc))
  subcld(c0, c1, w0)
  adantr(w0, wceq(c3, c0), wne(co(c0, cmin, c1), nat0))
  subne0d(c0, c1, w0)
  oveq1d(c3, cmin, c1, c0, wa(w0, wceq(c3, c0)))
  simpr(w0, wceq(c3, c0))
  simplr(w0, wcel(cneg(co(co(c3, cmin, c1), cdiv, co(c0, cmin, c1))), crp), wceq(c3, c0))
  necom(c3, c0)
}

blocks.name: angpieqvd
blocks.content: The angle ABC is ` _pi ` iff B is a nontrivial convex combination of A and C, i.e., iff B is in the interior of the segment AC. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm angpieqvd(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(wceq(co(co(c0, cmin, c1), c2, co(c3, cmin, c1)), cpi), wrex(s0, co(nat0, cioo, nat1), wceq(c1, co(co(cv(s0), cmul, c0), caddc, co(co(nat1, cmin, cv(s0)), cmul, c3))))))
  -| wceq(c2, cmpo(s1, s2, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), cfv(cim, cfv(clog, co(cv(s2), cdiv, cv(s1))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, c1))

blocks.name: chordthmlem
blocks.content: If M is the midpoint of AB and AQ = BQ, then QMB is a right angle. The proof uses ~ ssscongptld to observe that, since AMQ and BMQ have equal sides, the angles QMB and QMA must be equal. Since they are supplementary, both must be right. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: chordthmlem2
blocks.content: If M is the midpoint of AB, AQ = BQ, and P is on the line AB, then QMP is a right angle. This is proven by reduction to the special case ~ chordthmlem , where P = B, and using ~ angrtmuld to observe that QMP is right iff QMB is. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)

blocks.name: chordthmlem3
blocks.content: If M is the midpoint of AB, AQ = BQ, and P is on the line AB, then PQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> = QM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` + ` PM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>. This follows from ~ chordthmlem2 and the Pythagorean theorem ( ~ pythag ) in the case where P and Q are unequal to M. If either P or Q equals M, the result is trivial. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)

blocks.name: chordthmlem4
blocks.content: If P is on the segment AB and M is the midpoint of AB, then PA ` x. ` PB = BM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ` PM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>. If all lengths are reexpressed as fractions of AB, this reduces to the identity ` X x. ( 1 - X ) = ( 1 / 2 ) `<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ( ( 1 / 2 ) - X ) `<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)

blocks.name: chordthmlem5
blocks.content: If P is on the segment AB and AQ = BQ, then PA ` x. ` PB = BQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ` PQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>. This follows from two uses of ~ chordthmlem3 to show that PQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> = QM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` + ` PM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> and BQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> = QM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` + ` BM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>, so BQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ` PQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> = (QM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` + ` BM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>) ` - ` (QM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` + ` PM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>) = BM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ` PM<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>, which equals PA ` x. ` PB by ~ chordthmlem4 . (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: chordthm
blocks.content: The intersecting chords theorem. If points A, B, C, and D lie on a circle (with center Q, say), and the point P is on the interior of the segments AB and CD, then the two products of lengths PA ` x. ` PB and PC ` x. ` PD are equal. The Euclidean plane is identified with the complex plane, and the fact that P is on AB and on CD is expressed by the hypothesis that the angles APB and CPD are equal to ` _pi ` . The result is proven by using ~ chordthmlem5 twice to show that PA ` x. ` PB and PC ` x. ` PD both equal BQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ` PQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>. This is similar to the proof of the theorem given in Euclid's _Elements_, where it is Proposition III.35. This is Metamath 100 proof #55. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: heron
blocks.content: Heron's formula gives the area of a triangle given only the side lengths. If points A, B, C form a triangle, then the area of the triangle, represented here as ` ( 1 / 2 ) x. X x. Y x. abs ( sin O ) ` , is equal to the square root of ` S x. ( S - X ) x. ( S - Y ) x. ( S - Z ) ` , where ` S = ( X + Y + Z ) / 2 ` is half the perimeter of the triangle. Based on work by Jon Pennant. This is Metamath 100 proof #57. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 10-Mar-2019.)
blocks.origin:
